item.title: NINA Log Analyzer
item.description: NINA is a program for controlling astrophoto equipment. It creates text logs that are difficult to read. This web page allows displaying the log in a graph. It is based on ideas from Brian Carter.

item.title: À la recherche du temps perdu
item.description:
Exercise in using Mike Bostock’s D3 visualization framework.

Chronogram of Marcel Proust’s In Search of Lost Time, based on Jacques Darrieulat’s Chronoproust.

Each volume is represented as a rectangle of width proportional to its size, with time on the vertical axis.
The first volume starts around the birth of the Narrator, and there is a 10-year gap between the last two. Famously, the last volume, Le temps retrouvé ends around 1926, when the Narrator decides to start writing. Proust himself had died in 1922….

Try zooming in for more detail

item.title: Planet Path - Ecliptic projection
item.description: Displays the path of a planet during a given time frame in an ecliptic projection.

item.title: Zodiac
item.description: Displays Sun, Moon and planets, along with the constellations around the ecliptic in a rectangular projection.

item.title: Hourglass Diagram
item.description:
All astronomy yearbooks display some form of “hourglass” diagram, that shows the times when Sun, Moon and planets rise and set.
Finding the times for sunrise and sunset is easy enough, drawing the lines too. Coloring is more involved, but paper.js greatly helps.

item.title: Sunrise
item.description: Both HTML5 canvas and SVG have a “gradient” construct. This is an attempt to represent a sunrise with a circular gradient.

item.title: Moon Calendar
item.description: Once we know the phase from the date, we draw one little moon for each day of the year.

item.title: Gibbon's "Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire"
item.description:
Another example of a d3 interactive chart.
The horizontal scale shows the pages (in my Modern Library edition), and the vertical scale shows the years described at each chapter.

Hover mouse over curve to display the chapter title, zoom in for detail.
The long vertical bars represent chapters that span a long period.
